text:
The following content is
provided under a Creative
Commons license.

Your support will help
MIT OpenCourseWare

continue to offer high quality
educational resources for free.

To make a donation or to
view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare
at OCW.MIT.edu.

GUEST SPEAKER: All
right, everyone,

my name's [? Matt ?] Smith, and
I'm part of a group along with

[? Won-Jun, ?] Ryan, and
[? Chinya. ?] And we did

a project where we're using
Zemax to design a Cooke
triplet.

The Cooke triplet was
actually first designed
in the end of 1800s.

And here's a
picture on the right

there from the
original patent that
was designed back in the day.

But first, we'll talk about
what a Cooke triplet is,

a little bit about Zemax,
a bit about the aberrations
that it corrects.

Then we'll present some of our
results from the optimizations
that we ran.

GUEST SPEAKER: The
Cooke triplet is

composed of a negative flint
between two positive crowns.

Crowns have higher
V values, also

known as the
reciprocal dispersion,
compared to the flints.

The Cooke triplet is famous
for containing the smallest

number of elements that can
correct all seven Seidel
aberrations.

And the design principles used
include choice of lens powers

such that their sum is
approximately 0, the use

of space, positive
and negative lenses,

and the use of approximate
front to back symmetry.

So now we'll give a quick review
on the monochromatic Seidel

aberrations that we aimed
to minimize in our design.

The spherical aberration occurs
due to increased refraction

of rays further away
from the optical axis,

as the mechanism occurs when the
tangential and sagittal images
do not coincide.

Coma is defined as the variation
of magnification with aperture.

Field curvature occurs
when the curve--
sorry.

Field curvature is the
longitudinal departure

of focal surfaces from
the ideal image surface.

And distortion occurs when
the image of an off-axis point

forms further or closer
to the optical axis

compared to the image height
given by approximation.

GUEST SPEAKER: So
basically, for our design,

we chose to use
three simple lenses,

since it was basically
trying to make it the least
expensive thing to manufacture.

And it also cuts down a lot of
the difficulty with alignment.

The original patent
used compound lenses,

which give them much
more adjustability,

but it also made it
so that the system

was very difficult to
assemble and align correctly.

So we had a total of 14
variables, essentially.

There's the six curvatures,
two for each lens,

three lens thicknesses, two air
gaps, and three glass choices,

which we could all
vary to try to control
the aberrations in the system.

And so our first design
is this one right here.

It was optimized
to focus objects

at infinity to an image
plane 60 millimeters
behind the rear of the lens.

And for comparison, we also
designed the same system

using a single lens, which,
not surprisingly, has

a much harder time
focusing the light,

because it has much less
control over the aberrations.

These spot diagrams
basically give an idea

of what rays of light, coming
in from different angles

from infinity, are
focused by the system.

And you could see both
these are on the same scale.
The bar represents 1 millimeter.

So you can see here that the
single lens shows significantly

poorer focusing and
also at higher angles--

of high degree of coma coming
in, which is very detrimental
to the image--
the ability to focus any light.

And compared to
the Cooke triplet,

instead of the spots being
about 1 millimeter in radius,

they varied between
about 40 to 100 microns.

So significantly better focusing
and also much less coma.

At higher angles, there is
some astigmatism coming in,

which is hard to
see on this diagram,

but we can show you the
more detailed one later.

And to give you an overview
of the chromatic aberrations,

we compared the focal shift
for different wavelengths
for on-axis light.

These ones, basically they're
zeroed around green axis.

And the primary difference
between the two graphs
here is the scale.

This one varies from 0
to about 100 microns,

while the single
lens actually varies
from about 0 to 1,500 microns.

So overall, this Cooke
triplet reduces most

the aberrations here by
about an order of magnitude.

And next we compared the field
curvature and distortion.

These graphs both
have the Cooke triplet

and the single lens
plotted on the same graphs

to give you an idea of
their relative magnitudes.

And essentially, compared
to a single lens,

the Cooke triplet image
looks essentially flat with--

basically the maximum variation
in the field curvature
is about 50 microns.

Meanwhile, this one,
absolute variation

is largely dependent on the
height of the rays entering--

the angle of the rays
entering the lens

and varies by
several millimeters.

And the distortion also is
much worse for a single lens.

The Cooke triplet actually is
able to minimize distortion
until about 15 degrees--

the ray is coming in more
than 15 degrees off axis.

And essentially, the
original design parameters

that Taylor came up
with was to try and have

the sum of the
powers of the lenses

to be about equal to 0,
which effectively minimizes
field curvature and distortion.

And then we used the lens
curvatures and materials

to try and basically take
care of the other Seidel

aberrations, coma,
chromatic aberrations,
spherical aberrations.

And the last graphs we
have for this set of lenses

is the modulation
transfer function,

which gives you an idea of
how well they perform relative
to the diffraction limit.

So in this case,
aberrations essentially

serve as a phase
modulation on the--

or modulates the phase
of the transfer function.

So they will always be
less than or equal to 1,
so they can never increase it.

They can only decrease
the lens performance
below the diffraction limit.

And as you can see
for the single lens,

basically it drops
down very rapidly to 0

here, which greatly limits the
amount of spatial frequency
the lens can focus.

But the Cooke triplet, while
it does operate significantly

below the diffraction
limit, still

can capture much higher
spatial frequencies

and focus them, which resulted
in the much sharper spot

diagrams we saw in
the previous slide.

GUEST SPEAKER: Next we
explored the optimization

with different image distances
between the dense lens
system and some image plane.

First of all, the
system had been

optimized with the
100-millimeter image distance.

And next the thickness of
lens, and coverage of lens,

and space between our
lens were optimized

with the 50-millimeter and
30-millimeter image distances.

In this case, we fixed
the types of glasses,

and we only used
these 11 variables.

Although, the short
image distance

may require some thicker glasses
for both the positive lens.

Though, this first positive
lens was very sensitive
for this optimization process.

On the contrary, the space
between this negative lens

and second positive lens was
changed from 6.6 millimeter
to 8.12 millimeter.

About the aberration, we can see
the increase of most aberration

with the decrease of
the image distances.

If we compare it with
some single lens cases,

we can see most
abrasion decreased one
or two order of magnitude.

It means that the Cooke
triplet is very robust system,

and this point is very positive
for camera or some production

system that are used in
some various image distance.

Also, we made more constraint to
control the design parameters.

[INAUDIBLE] glass
thickness constraints

were added as the
initial condition.

In this case, the
initial glass thickness

was fixed at some optimized
value for 100-millimeter image
distance.

And we can evaluate
the [INAUDIBLE]
in this Cook triplet system.

First of all, the space
between the negative lens

and second positive lens
expanded from 30 millimeter
to 15.5 millimeter.

And next the space between first
positive lens and negative lens

was decreased from 5.2
millimeter to 2.5 millimeter.

This means that in spite of
the decrease of image distance,

the Cooke triplet requires
a similar or larger space
to optimize this system.

Also, though most aberrations
were magnified in comparison

with these previous three
glass thickness cases,

but is still better than
some single lens case.

GUEST SPEAKER: Next we
optimized the glasses used
in a Cooke triplet pattern.

As seen here, [INAUDIBLE]
for glass optimization,

we only varied glass,
and we kept the spaces

between the lenses
and image distance

constant with minimal
changes to the curvatures.

After optimization
in Zemax, the glasses

changed such that the negative
element has the same refractive

index and higher dispersion,
while the positive element has

a higher refractive index and
higher dispersion compared
to the original glasses.

We can see that there's
a significant increase
in the refractive index--

difference between the
crown and the flint
in the optimized design.

So here are the outputs
for comparing the pattern
and the optimized design.

We can see that the optimized
designs give better images.

And from the field curvature
and the distortion plots,

we can see there's a
reduction in field curvature
in distortion from the--
sorry.

From of the spot
diagram, we can see

that there's reduction
in astigmatism and coma.

And then from the
plot below, we can

see that the optimized
design gives a shorter

range of focus shift,
which implies a reduction
in chromatic aberration.
GUEST SPEAKER: Let's try that.

So once you have
your optimal design,
it's important to understand--

kind of what the
previous group did--

understand how much you
can vary your alignment

and your thicknessnes
from a manufacturing sense

and see how that influences
where you are in the optimum.

So what we did here was took
the first plot that Ryan showed,
the full optimization.
We had 14 design variables.

And what we did is went
through and changed--
perturbed each surface slightly.

So we perturbed each
surface between plus/minus 1
millimeter.

So this plot is for
the first surface here.

This plot is for the
[INAUDIBLE] surface here.

And the horizontal axis is the
change from the optimal design
point.

So 0 means you're
at the optimal rays
of curvature for that surface.

And then as you subtract off
millimeters or add millimeters,

that's perturbing around
the optimal point.

The vertical axis is
the Seidel coefficient
for a given Seidel aberration.

And the Seidel coefficient
is measured in waves,

and it's an indication of how
much of a particular aberration

you have present
in your wavefront.

And one thing to notice,
comparing the first surface

and the last surface, is that
the first lens is highly curved
compared to the last surface.

So the optimal value
for the first surface
is about 26 millimeters.

For the last surface, it's
negative 43 millimeters.

So the first lens is
relatively highly curved,

which means that its
contribution to distortion
is much more pronounced.

So this pink line is
distortion, and you

can see the slope is much
greater here as compared
to the last surface.

And that actually applies
to the other aberrations,

too, that changing the
curvature on the first surface--

the first surface is
really sensitive to changes
in curvature.

So what's happening,
basically, is the first surface

is doing most of the work
bending light and doing
the imaging.

So the downstream
lenses are essentially

correcting for the aberrations
introduced by the first imaging
lens.

If you look at the root mean
square of these aberrations,

which is what Zemax
is trying to minimize,

you notice that for
the first surface,

there is a little
local minimum here,

whereas for the last
surface, there actually is
no local minimum on the plot.

And that's actually true for all
the surfaces besides the first.

And the reason for that is
because the first surface

is most sensitive to changes,
and it bends light the most.

So Zemax is going to try
to get that first surface
to a minimum.

If that first surface
wasn't at a minimum, then

it wouldn't matter what you
did downstream from there,

because this dominates the
aberrations that you're
introducing.

We did the same
thing tolerancing
the spaces between the lenses.

So what you see is that the
second space, the distance

between the second lens
and the third lens,

is much more sensitive
than the first space,

particularly when it
comes to distortion.

Also notice that field curvature
is constant for tolerancing
the spaces.

And that's because
field curvature

isn't dependent on the
position of the lens,

only on the power of
the lens, because that's

what field curvature is is a
change in the focusing point
as you go off axis.

And that's not
going to be changed

by the space of the relative
spacing of the lenses.
So just a few conclusions here.

Basically, what I said
before is that the first lens

of the triplet is what dominates
the aberration, because it

sort of does most of
the work for imaging.

So if you were to
make the first lens

some sort of more complicated
aspheric element that

had fewer Seidel
aberrations to begin with,

your performance would
greatly increase,

because the downstream lenses
wouldn't have to correct
as much from the get go.

All the design variables,
those 14 design variables,
are highly interdependent.

So it makes the
optimization a challenge.

So if you change one
radius of curvature,

you don't just get one
Seidel aberration change.

You get all of them
changing in coupled ways.

So it's a highly
coupled problem,

and we had to run on the
order of a billion iterations

for our big
optimization in order
to converge on a solution.

But in general,
the Cooke triplet

does do a good job of
reducing the Seidel operations

for maintaining a
relatively large aperture
relative to its focal length.

And I guess for its
time, it was, I guess,

the fastest lens
that was available.

And so even though it was
designed over 100 years ago,

it still remains a relatively
optimal design, I guess.

So here are our
references, and we'd
be happy to take questions.
[CLAPPING]
PROFESSOR: Questions?
[INAUDIBLE], yeah, go ahead.

AUDIENCE: What optimization
algorithm did you use?
So two questions.

What optimization did you
use, and how did you decide
to define your merit function?

GUEST SPEAKER: For
the optimization,
we essentially asked it--

it was primarily minimizing
the Seidel aberrations
on the image plane.

And then we also basically
set reasonable constraints

on the lens parameters to make
sure-- like keep the thickness

below 20 millimeters, set a
range on the acceptable radius
and so on.

And then essentially,
the rest of the things
we made variables.

This image shows basically
the Zemax user interface.

And so here's where we defined
the merit function, which
solves for the coma.

The primary aberrations
then sets constraints
on the lens parameters.

And here's where we
define the initial values

and also what we wanted
to use for as a variable
in each simulation.

So this one's set to vary
all the curvatures, all

the distances, and the
glass types, which results--

theoretically if
you want to test

10 things for each one, that's
10 to the 14th variables,

but Zemax is good at
sifting through that

to reduce the
number of tests you
have to do to find the optimum.

In this case, we ran
about 10 to the 10.
Any other questions?

PROFESSOR: You mentioned
that the higher the flint,

the better the chromatic
aberration capability.
Is it the same iteration?

For example, I think
you explained very well

why the curvature
of the first lens

is very important for
the correction, right.

Is that a similar explanation
for why the flint is important?

GUEST SPEAKER:
The essential idea

is that since the two
positive lenses are

doing most of the primary
amount of the imaging,

we wanted to keep the
dispersion low there.
And then the third--

the negative lens
was less critical.

I don't know,
[? Chinya, ?] did you
find a reason why that varied?
GUEST SPEAKER: [INAUDIBLE]
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

GUEST SPEAKER: We only
varied the refractive index
and the dispersion.

So you're referring to
the height of the flint?
PROFESSOR: Yeah.

GUEST SPEAKER: We actually kept
the shape basically the same.

It's only either refractive
index and the dispersion that

changes, so I'm
not sure about how

the height of the
[INAUDIBLE] will actually
affect the design.

GUEST SPEAKER:
Well, in this case,

the size of the
negative lens actually

sets the aperture
for the system,

instead of actually using
diaphragm stops, which

is what cameras at the
time had to rely on

to minimize aberrations,
which severely limited

the amount of light
they could collect.

So in this case, the size of
the negative flint element

essentially sets how much
light the rest of the system
can collect.

And the two positive lenses
were scaled relative to it.

PROFESSOR: Any questions
from Singapore?
Singapore is very quiet.

Is it because you guys had
to be temperature tested
before you came to class, or--

you guys here don't know,
but in Singapore, they

are very worried
about the swine flu.

So there is a military guard
in front of each building,

and they actually take
their temperature with--

you guys have IR viewers, I
think, or something, right?

AUDIENCE: Yeah, he
has a thermometer.
[LAUGHTER]
Yeah, he has a thermometer here.

PROFESSOR And every day,
they have to email--

at least the staff in the
resident center where I work,

you have to email your
temperature every day
and fill out a form, yeah.
It's very interesting.

AUDIENCE: Yeah,
I had a question.

You mentioned that the Seidel
aberrations have coupled.

So if you defined a
pupil for your system

and used Zernike
polynomials, would you

be able to uncouple
the aberrations, and--

I mean the Zernike
polynomials are

orthogonal basis for
wavefront in the pupil plane.
So does Zemax do that?

GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah, so
Zemax does tell you what
the Zernike polynomials are.

It'll decompose your wavefront
into Zernike polynomials
for you.

What I was referring
to was the fact

that the Seidel coefficients
are coupled in the sense

that if you change one
variable, more than one Seidel
aberration is affected.

And because the
Seidel aberrations

can be mapped onto Zernikes,
the same thing would apply.

So changing one
variable would also

change some linear
combination of Zernikes,
rather than just one Zernike.

So it'd still be coupled,
even though you're

representing the aberrations
in an orthogonal way.
Anyone else?
PROFESSOR: OK, thank you.
[CLAPPING]
